25.35: David accepted the food Abigail had brought. "Don't worry," he said. "You can go home now. I'll do what you asked."
25.36: Abigail went back home and found Nabal throwing a party fit for a king. He was very drunk and feeling good, so she didn't tell him anything that night.
25.37: But when he sobered up the next morning, Abigail told him everything that had happened. Nabal had a heart attack, and he lay in bed as still as a stone.
25.38: Ten days later, the LORD took his life.
25.41: She bowed down and said, "I would willingly be David's slave and wash his servants' feet."
25.42: Abigail quickly got ready and went back with David's messengers. She rode on her donkey, while five of her servant women walked alongside. She and David were married as soon as she arrived.
25.43: David had earlier married Ahinoam from the town of Jezreel, so both she and Abigail were now David's wives.
25.44: Meanwhile, Saul had arranged for Michal to marry Palti the son of Laish, who came from the town of Gallim.

26.1: Once again, some people from Ziph went to Gibeah to talk with Saul. "David has a hideout on Mount Hachilah near Jeshimon out in the desert," they told him.
26.2: Saul took 3,000 of Israel's best soldiers and went to look for David there in Ziph Desert.
26.3: Saul set up camp on Mount Hachilah, which is across the road from Jeshimon. But David was hiding out in the desert. When David heard that Saul was following him,
26.4: he sent some spies to find out if it was true.
26.5: Then he sneaked up to Saul's camp. He noticed that Saul and his army commander Abner the son of Ner were sleeping in the middle of the camp, with soldiers sleeping all around them.
26.6: David asked Ahimelech the Hittite and Joab's brother Abishai, "Which one of you will go with me into Saul's camp?" "I will!" Abishai answered.
26.7: That same night, David and Abishai crept into the camp. Saul was sleeping, and his spear was stuck in the ground not far from his head. Abner and the soldiers were sound asleep all around him.
26.8: Abishai whispered, "This time God has let you get your hands on your enemy! I'll pin him to the ground with one thrust of his own spear."
26.9: "Don't kill him!" David whispered back. "The LORD will punish anyone who kills his chosen king.
26.10: As surely as the LORD lives, the LORD will kill Saul, or Saul will die a natural death or be killed in battle.
26.11: But I pray that the LORD will keep me from harming his chosen king. Let's grab his spear and his water jar and get out of here!"
26.12: David took the spear and the water jar, then left the camp. None of Saul's soldiers knew what had happened or even woke up--the LORD had made all of them fall sound asleep.
26.13: David and Abishai crossed the valley and went to the top of the next hill, where they were at a safe distance.
26.14: "Abner!" David shouted toward Saul's army. "Can you hear me?" Abner shouted back. "Who dares disturb the king?"
26.15: "Abner, what kind of a man are you?" David replied. "Aren't you supposed to be the best soldier in Israel? Then why didn't you protect your king? Anyone who went into your camp could have killed him tonight.
26.16: You're a complete failure! I swear by the living LORD that you and your men deserve to die for not protecting the LORD's chosen king. Look and see if you can find the king's spear and the water jar that were near his head."
26.17: Saul could tell it was David's voice, and he called out, "David, my son! Is that you?" "Yes it is, Your Majesty.
26.18: Why are you hunting me down? Have I done something wrong, or have I committed a crime?
26.19: Please listen to what I have to say. If the LORD has turned you against me, maybe a sacrifice will make him change his mind. But if some people have turned you against me, I hope the LORD will punish them! They have forced me to leave the land that belongs to the LORD and have told me to worship foreign gods.
26.20: Don't let me die in a land far away from the LORD. I'm no more important than a flea! Why should the king of Israel hunt me down as if I were a bird in the mountains?"
26.21: "David, you had the chance to kill me today. But you didn't. I was very wrong about you. It was a terrible mistake for me to try to kill you. I've acted like a fool, but I'll never try to harm you again. You're like a son to me, so please come back."
26.22: "Your Majesty, here's your spear! Let one of your soldiers come and get it.
26.23: The LORD put you in my power today, but you are his chosen king and I wouldn't harm you. The LORD rewards people who are faithful and live right.
26.24: I spared your life today, and I pray that the LORD will spare my life and keep me safe."
26.25: "David, my son, I pray that the Lord will bless you and make you successful!" Saul went back home. David also left,

27.1: but he thought to himself, "One of these days, Saul is going to kill me. The only way to escape from him is to go to Philistia. Then I'll be outside of Israel, and Saul will give up trying to catch me."
27.4: When Saul found out that David had run off to Gath, he stopped trying to catch him.
27.5: One day, David was talking with Achish and said, "If you are happy with me, then let me live in one of the towns in the countryside. I'm not important enough to live here with you in the royal city."
27.6: Achish gave David the town of Ziklag that same day, and Ziklag has belonged to the kings of Judah ever since.
27.7: David was in Philistia for a year and four months.
27.8: The Geshurites, the Girzites, and the Amalekites lived in the area from Telam to Shur and on as far as Egypt, and David often attacked their towns.
27.9: Whenever David and his men attacked a town, they took the sheep, cattle, donkeys, camels, and the clothing, and killed everyone who lived there. After he returned from a raid, David always went to see Achish,
27.10: who would ask, "Where did you attack today?" David would answer, "Oh, we attacked some desert town that belonged to the Judah tribe." Sometimes David would say, "Oh, we attacked a town in the desert where the Jerahmeel clan lives" or "We attacked a town in the desert where the Kenites live."
27.11: That's why David killed everyone in the towns he attacked. He thought, "If I let any of them live, they might come to Gath and tell what I've really been doing." David made these raids all the time he was in Philistia.
27.12: But Achish trusted David and thought, "David's people must be furious with him. From now on he will have to take orders from me."

28.4: The Philistines went to Shunem and set up camp. Saul called the army of Israel together, and they set up their camp in Gilboa.
28.5: Saul took one look at the Philistine army and started shaking with fear.
28.6: So he asked the LORD what to do. But the LORD would not answer, either in a dream or by a priest or a prophet.
28.7: Then Saul told his officers, "Find me a woman who can talk to the spirits of the dead. I'll go to her and find out what's going to happen." His servants told him, "There's a woman at Endor who can talk to spirits of the dead."
28.8: That night, Saul put on different clothing so nobody would recognize him. Then he and two of his men went to the woman, and asked, "Will you bring up the ghost of someone for us?"
28.9: The woman said, "Why are you trying to trick me and get me killed? You know King Saul has killed everyone who talks to the spirits of the dead!"
28.10: Saul replied, "I swear by the living LORD that nothing will happen to you because of this."
28.11: "Who do you want me to bring up?" she asked. "Bring up the ghost of Samuel," he answered.
28.12: When the woman saw Samuel, she screamed. Then she turned to Saul and said, "You've tricked me! You're the king!"
28.13: "Don't be afraid," Saul replied. "Just tell me what you see." She answered, "I see a spirit rising up out of the ground."
28.14: "What does it look like?" "It looks like an old man wearing a robe." Saul knew it was Samuel, so he bowed down low.
28.15: "Why are you bothering me by bringing me up like this?" Samuel asked. "I'm terribly worried," Saul answered. "The Philistines are about to attack me. God has turned his back on me and won't answer any more by prophets or by dreams. What should I do?"
28.16: Samuel said: If the LORD has turned away from you and is now your enemy, don't ask me what to do.
28.17: I've already told you: The LORD has sworn to take the kingdom from you and give it to David. And that's just what he's doing!
28.18: When the LORD was angry with the Amalekites, he told you to destroy them, but you didn't do it. That's why the LORD is doing this to you.
28.19: Tomorrow the LORD will let the Philistines defeat Israel's army, then you and your sons will join me down here in the world of the dead.
28.20: At once, Saul collapsed and lay stretched out on the floor, terrified at what Samuel had said. He was weak because he had not eaten anything since the day before.
28.21: The woman came over to Saul, and when she saw that he was completely terrified, she said, "Your Majesty, I listened to you and risked my life to do what you asked.
28.22: Now please listen to me. Let me get you a little something to eat. It will give you strength for your walk back to camp."
28.23: "No, I won't eat!" But his officers and the woman kept on urging Saul, until he finally agreed. He got up off the floor and sat on the bed.
28.24: At once the woman killed a calf that she had been fattening up. She cooked part of the meat and baked some thin bread.
28.25: Then she served the food to Saul and his officers, who ate and left before daylight.

29.1: The Philistines had brought their whole army to Aphek, while Israel's army was camping near Jezreel Spring.
29.4: The Philistine army commanders were angry and shouted: Send David back to the town you gave him. We won't have him going into the battle with us. He could turn and fight against us! Saul would take David back as an officer if David brought him the heads of our soldiers.
29.5: The Israelites even dance and sing, "Saul has killed a thousand enemies; David has killed ten thousand!"
29.6: Achish called David over and said: I swear by the living LORD that you've been honest with me, and I want you to fight by my side. I don't think you've done anything wrong from the day you joined me until this very moment. But the other Philistine rulers don't want you to come along.
29.7: Go on back home and try not to upset them.
29.8: "But what have I done?" David asked. "Do you know of anything I've ever done that would keep me from fighting the enemies of my king?"
29.9: Achish said: I believe that you're as good as an angel of God, but our army commanders have decided that you can't fight in this battle.
29.10: You and your troops will have to go back to the town I gave you. Get up and leave tomorrow morning as soon as it's light. I'm pleased with you, so don't let any of this bother you.
29.11: David and his men got up early in the morning and headed back toward Philistia, while the Philistines left for Jezreel.

30.1: It took David and his men three days to reach Ziklag. But while they had been away, the Amalekites had been raiding in the desert around there. They had attacked Ziklag, burned it to the ground,
30.2: and had taken away the women and children.
30.3: When David and his men came to Ziklag, they saw the burned-out ruins and learned that their families had been taken captive.
30.4: They started crying and kept it up until they were too weak to cry any more.
30.5: David's two wives, Ahinoam and Abigail, had been taken captive with everyone else.
30.6: David was desperate. His soldiers were so upset over what had happened to their sons and daughters that they were thinking about stoning David to death. But he felt the LORD God giving him strength,
30.7: and he said to the priest, "Abiathar, let's ask God what to do." Abiathar brought everything he needed to get answers from God, and he went over to David.
30.8: Then David asked the LORD, "Should I go after the people who raided our town? Can I catch up with them?" "Go after them," the LORD answered. "You will catch up with them, and you will rescue your families."
30.11: Some of David's men found an Egyptian out in a field and took him to David. They gave the Egyptian some bread, and he ate it. Then they gave him a drink of water,
30.12: some dried figs, and two handfuls of raisins. This was the first time in three days he had tasted food or water. Now he felt much better.
30.13: "Who is your master?" David asked. "And where do you come from?" "I'm from Egypt," the young man answered. "I'm the servant of an Amalekite, but he left me here three days ago because I was sick.
30.14: We had attacked some towns in the desert where the Cherethites live, in the area that belongs to Judah, and in the desert where the Caleb clan lives. And we burned down Ziklag."
30.15: "Will you take me to those Amalekites?" David asked. "Yes, I will, if you promise with God as a witness that you won't kill me or hand me over to my master."
30.16: He led David to the Amalekites. They were eating and drinking everywhere, celebrating because of what they had taken from Philistia and Judah.
30.17: David attacked just before sunrise the next day and fought until sunset. Four hundred Amalekites rode away on camels, but they were the only ones who escaped.
30.18: David rescued his two wives and everyone else the Amalekites had taken from Ziklag.
30.19: No one was missing--young or old, sons or daughters. David brought back everything that had been stolen,
30.20: including their livestock. David also took the sheep and cattle that the Amalekites had with them, but he kept these separate from the others. Everyone agreed that these would be David's reward.
30.21: On the way back, David went to the 200 men he had left at Besor Gorge, because they had been too tired to keep up with him. They came toward David and the people who were with him. When David was close enough, he greeted the 200 men and asked how they were doing.
30.22: Some of David's men were good-for-nothings, and they said, "Those men didn't go with us to the battle, so they don't get any of the things we took back from the Amalekites. Let them take their wives and children and go!"
30.23: But David said: My friends, don't be so greedy with what the LORD has given us! The LORD protected us and gave us victory over the people who attacked.
30.24: Who would pay attention to you, anyway? Soldiers who stay behind to guard the camp get as much as those who go into battle.
30.25: David made this a law for Israel, and it has been the same ever since.
30.26: David went back to Ziklag with everything they had taken from the Amalekites. He sent some of these things as gifts to his friends who were leaders of Judah, and he told them, "We took these things from the LORD's enemies. Please accept them as a gift."

31.1: Meanwhile, the Philistines were fighting Israel at Mount Gilboa. Israel's soldiers ran from the Philistines, and many of them were killed.
31.2: The Philistines closed in on Saul and his sons, and they killed his sons Jonathan, Abinadab, and Malchishua.
31.3: The fighting was fierce around Saul, and he was badly wounded by enemy arrows.
31.4: Saul told the soldier who carried his weapons, "Kill me with your sword! I don't want these worthless Philistines to torture and make fun of me." But the soldier was afraid to kill him. Saul then took out his own sword; he stuck the blade into his stomach, and fell on it.
31.5: When the soldier knew that Saul was dead, he killed himself in the same way.
31.6: Saul was dead, his three sons were dead, and the soldier who carried his weapons was dead. They and all his soldiers died on that same day.
31.7: The Israelites on the other side of Jezreel Valley and the other side of the Jordan learned that Saul and his sons were dead. They saw that the Israelite army had run away. So they ran away too, and the Philistines moved into the towns the Israelites had left behind.
31.8: The day after the battle, when the Philistines returned to the battlefield to take the weapons of the dead Israelite soldiers, they found Saul and his three sons lying dead on Mount Gilboa.
31.11: The people who lived in Jabesh in Gilead heard what the Philistines had done to Saul's body.
31.12: So one night, some brave men from Jabesh went to Beth-Shan. They took down the bodies of Saul and his sons, then brought them back to Jabesh and burned them.
31.13: They buried the bones under a small tree in Jabesh, and for seven days, they went without eating to show their sorrow.

1.1: Saul was dead. Meanwhile, David had defeated the Amalekites and returned to Ziklag.
1.2: Three days later, a soldier came from Saul's army. His clothes were torn, and dirt was on his head. He went to David and knelt down in front of him.
1.3: David asked, "Where did you come from?" The man answered, "From Israel's army. I barely escaped with my life."
1.4: "Who won the battle?" David asked. The man said, "Our army turned and ran, but many were wounded and died. Even King Saul and his son Jonathan are dead."
1.5: David asked, "How do you know Saul and Jonathan are dead?"
1.6: The young man replied: I was on Mount Gilboa and saw King Saul leaning on his spear. The enemy's war chariots and cavalry were closing in on him.
1.7: When he turned around and saw me, he called me over. I went and asked what he wanted.
1.8: Saul asked me, "Who are you?" "An Amalekite," I answered.
1.9: Then he said, "Kill me! I'm dying, and I'm in terrible pain."
1.10: So I killed him. I knew he was too badly wounded to live much longer. Then I took his crown and his arm-band, and I brought them to you, Your Majesty. Here they are.
1.11: At once, David and his soldiers tore their clothes in sorrow.
1.12: They cried all day long and would not eat anything. Everyone was sad because Saul, his son Jonathan, and many of the LORD's people had been killed in the battle.
1.13: David asked the young man, "Where is your home?" The man replied, "My father is an Amalekite, but we live in Israel."
1.17: David sang a song in memory of Saul and Jonathan,
1.18: and he ordered his men to teach the song to everyone in Judah. He called it "The Song of the Bow," and it can be found in The Book of Jashar. This is the song:
1.19: Israel, your famous hero lies dead on the hills, and your mighty warriors have fallen!
1.20: Don't tell it in Gath or spread the news on the streets of Ashkelon. The godless Philistine women will be happy and jump for joy.
1.21: Don't let dew or rain fall on the hills of Gilboa. Don't let its fields grow offerings for God. There the warriors' shields were smeared with mud, and Saul's own shield was left unpolished.
1.22: The arrows of Jonathan struck, and warriors died. The sword of Saul cut the enemy apart.
1.23: It was easy to love Saul and Jonathan. Together in life, together in death, they were faster than eagles and stronger than lions.
1.24: Women of Israel, cry for Saul. He brought you fine red cloth and jewelry made of gold.
1.25: Our warriors have fallen in the heat of battle, and Jonathan lies dead on the hills of Gilboa.
1.26: Jonathan, I miss you most! I loved you like a brother. You were truly loyal to me, more faithful than a wife to her husband.
1.27: Our warriors have fallen, and their weapons are destroyed.

2.1: Later, David asked the LORD, "Should I go back to one of the towns of Judah?" The LORD answered, "Yes." David asked, "Which town should I go to?" "Go to Hebron," the LORD replied.
2.2: David went to Hebron with his two wives, Ahinoam and Abigail. Ahinoam was from Jezreel, and Abigail was the widow of Nabal from Carmel.
2.3: David also told his men and their families to come and live in the villages near Hebron.
2.4: The people of Judah met with David at Hebron and poured olive oil on his head to show that he was their new king. Then they told David, "The people from Jabesh in Gilead buried Saul."
2.5: David sent messengers to tell them: The LORD bless you! You were kind enough to bury Saul your ruler,
2.6: and I pray that the LORD will be kind and faithful to you. I will be your friend because of what you have done.
2.7: Saul is dead, but the tribe of Judah has made me their king. So be strong and have courage.
2.8: Abner the son of Ner had been the general of Saul's army. He took Saul's son Ishbosheth across the Jordan River to Mahanaim
2.9: and made him king of Israel, including the areas of Gilead, Asher, Jezreel, Ephraim, and Benjamin.
2.10: Ishbosheth was 40 years old at the time, and he ruled for two years. But the tribe of Judah made David their king,
2.11: and he ruled from Hebron for seven and a half years.
2.12: One day, Abner and the soldiers of Ishbosheth left Mahanaim and went to Gibeon.
2.13: Meanwhile, Joab the son of Zeruiah was leading David's soldiers, and the two groups met at the pool in Gibeon. Abner and his men sat down on one side of the pool, while Joab and his men sat on the other side.
2.14: Abner yelled to Joab, "Let's get some of our best soldiers to stand up and fight each other!" Joab agreed,
2.15: and twelve of Ishbosheth's men from the tribe of Benjamin got up to fight twelve of David's men.
2.16: They grabbed each other by the hair and stabbed each other in the side with their daggers. They all died right there! That's why the place in Gibeon is called "Field of Daggers."
2.17: Then everyone started fighting. Both sides fought very hard, but David's soldiers defeated Abner and the soldiers of Israel.
2.18: Zeruiah's three sons were there: Joab, Abishai, and Asahel. Asahel could run as fast as a deer in an open field,
2.19: and he ran straight after Abner, without looking to the right or to the left.
2.20: When Abner turned and saw him, he said, "Is that you, Asahel?" Asahel answered, "Yes it is."
2.21: Abner said, "There are soldiers all around. Stop chasing me and fight one of them! Kill him and take his clothes and weapons for yourself." But Asahel refused to stop.
2.22: Abner said, "If you don't turn back, I'll have to kill you! Then I could never face your brother Joab again."
2.23: But Asahel would not turn back, so Abner struck him in the stomach with the back end of his spear. The spear went all the way through and came out of his back. Asahel fell down and died. Everyone who saw Asahel lying dead just stopped and stood still.
2.24: But Joab and Abishai went after Abner. Finally, about sunset, they came to the hill of Ammah, not far from Giah on the road to Gibeon Desert.
2.25: Abner brought the men of Benjamin together in one group on top of a hill, and they got ready to fight.
2.26: Abner shouted to Joab, "Aren't we ever going to stop killing each other? Don't you know that the longer we keep on doing this, the worse it's going to be when it's all over? When are you going to order your men to stop chasing their own relatives?"
2.27: Joab shouted back, "I swear by the living God, if you hadn't spoken, my men would have chased their relatives all night!"
2.28: Joab took his trumpet and blew the signal for his soldiers to stop chasing the soldiers of Israel. At once, the fighting stopped.
2.29: Abner and his troops marched through the Jordan River valley all that night. Then they crossed the river and marched all morning until they arrived back at Mahanaim.
2.30: As soon as Joab stopped chasing Abner, he got David's troops together and counted them. There were 19 missing besides Asahel.
2.31: But David's soldiers had killed 360 of Abner's men from the tribe of Benjamin.
2.32: Joab and his troops carried Asahel's body to Bethlehem and buried him in the family burial place. Then they marched all night and reached Hebron before sunrise.

3.1: This battle was the beginning of a long war between the followers of Saul and the followers of David. Saul's power grew weaker, but David's grew stronger.
3.6: As the war went on between the families of David and Saul, Abner was gaining more power than ever in Saul's family.
3.7: He had even slept with a wife of Saul by the name of Rizpah the daughter of Aiah. But Saul's son Ishbosheth told Abner, "You shouldn't have slept with one of my father's wives!"
3.8: Abner was very angry because of what Ishbosheth had said, and he told Ishbosheth: Am I some kind of worthless dog from Judah? I've always been loyal to your father's family and to his relatives and friends. I haven't turned you over to David. And yet you talk to me as if I've committed a crime with this woman.
3.9: I ask God to punish me if I don't help David get what the LORD promised him!
3.10: God said that he wouldn't let anyone in Saul's family ever be king again and that David would be king instead. He also said that David would rule both Israel and Judah, all the way from Dan in the north to Beersheba in the south.
3.11: Ishbosheth was so afraid of Abner that he could not even answer.
3.12: Abner sent some of his men to David with this message: "You should be the ruler of the whole nation. If you make an agreement with me, I will persuade everyone in Israel to make you their king."
3.13: David sent this message back: "Good! I'll make an agreement with you. But before I will even talk with you about it, you must get Saul's daughter Michal back for me."
3.14: David sent a few of his officials to Ishbosheth to give him this message: "Give me back my wife Michal! I killed 100 Philistines so I could marry her."
3.15: Ishbosheth sent some of his men to take Michal away from her new husband, Paltiel the son of Laish.
3.16: Paltiel followed Michal and the men all the way to Bahurim, crying as he walked. But he went back home after Abner ordered him to leave.
3.17: Abner talked with the leaders of the tribes of Israel and told them, "You've wanted to make David your king for a long time now.
3.18: So do it! After all, God said he would use his servant David to rescue his people Israel from their enemies, especially from the Philistines."
3.19: Finally, Abner talked with the tribe of Benjamin. Then he left for Hebron to tell David everything that the tribe of Benjamin and the rest of the people of Israel wanted to do.
3.20: Abner took 20 soldiers with him, and when they got to Hebron, David gave a big feast for them.
3.21: After the feast, Abner said, "Your Majesty, let me leave now and bring Israel here to make an agreement with you. You'll be king of the whole nation, just as you've been wanting." David told Abner he could leave, and he left without causing any trouble.
3.22: Soon after Abner had left Hebron, Joab and some of David's soldiers came back, bringing a lot of things they had taken from an enemy village.
3.23: Right after they arrived, someone told Joab, "Abner visited the king, and the king let him go. Abner even left without causing any trouble."
3.24: Joab went to David and said, "What have you done? Abner came to you, and you let him go. Now he's long gone!
3.25: You know Abner--he came to trick you. He wants to find out how strong your army is and to know everything you're doing."
3.26: Joab left David, then he sent some messengers to catch up with Abner. They brought him back from the well at Sirah, but David did not know anything about it.
3.27: When Abner returned to Hebron, Joab pretended he wanted to talk privately with him. So he took Abner into one of the small rooms that were part of the town gate and stabbed him in the stomach. Joab killed him because Abner had killed Joab's brother Asahel.
3.28: David heard how Joab had killed Abner, and he said, "I swear to the LORD that I am completely innocent of Abner's death!
3.29: Joab and his family are the guilty ones. I pray that Joab's family will always be sick with sores and other skin diseases. May they all be cowards, and may they die in war or starve to death."
3.30: Joab and his brother Abishai killed Abner because he had killed their brother Asahel in the battle at Gibeon.
3.31: David told Joab and everyone with him, "Show your sorrow by tearing your clothes and wearing sackcloth! Walk in front of Abner's body and cry!" David walked behind the stretcher on which Abner's body was being carried.
3.32: Abner was buried in Hebron, while David and everyone else stood at the tomb and cried loudly.
3.33: Then the king sang a funeral song about Abner: Abner, why should you have died like an outlaw?
3.34: No one tied your hands or chained your feet, yet you died as a victim of murderers. Everyone started crying again.
3.35: Then they brought some food to David and told him he would feel better if he had something to eat. It was still daytime, and David said, "I swear to God that I won't take a bite of bread or anything else until sunset!"
3.36: Everyone noticed what David did, and they liked it, just as they always liked what he did.
3.37: Now the people of Judah and Israel were certain that David had nothing to do with killing Abner.
3.38: David said to his officials, "Don't you realize that today one of Israel's great leaders has died?
3.39: I am the chosen king, but Joab and Abishai have more power than I do. So God will have to pay them back for the evil thing they did."

4.1: Ishbosheth felt like giving up after he heard that Abner had died in Hebron. Everyone in Israel was terrified.
4.2: Ishbosheth had put the two brothers Baanah and Rechab in charge of the soldiers who raided enemy villages. Rimmon was their father, and they were from the town of Beeroth, which belonged to the tribe of Benjamin.
4.3: The people who used to live in Beeroth had run away to Gittaim, and they still live there.
4.4: Saul's son Jonathan had a son named Mephibosheth, who had not been able to walk since he was five years old. It happened when someone from Jezreel told his nurse that Saul and Jonathan had died. She hurried off with the boy in her arms, but he fell and injured his legs.
4.5: One day about noon, Rechab and Baanah went to Ishbosheth's house. It was a hot day, and he was resting
4.8: Finally they turned west and went to Hebron. They went in to see David and told him, "Your Majesty, here is the head of Ishbosheth, the son of your enemy Saul who tried to kill you! The LORD has let you get even with Saul and his family."
4.9: David answered: I swear that only the LORD rescues me when I'm in trouble!
4.10: When a man came to Ziklag and told me that Saul was dead, he thought he deserved a reward for bringing good news. But I grabbed him and killed him.
4.11: You evil men have done something much worse than he did. You've killed an innocent man in his own house and on his own bed. I'll make you pay for that. I'll wipe you from the face of the earth!
4.12: Then David said to his troops, "Kill these two brothers! Cut off their hands and feet and hang their bodies by the pool in Hebron. But bury Ishbosheth's head in Abner's tomb near Hebron." And they did.

5.1: Israel's leaders met with David at Hebron and said, "We are your relatives.
5.2: Even when Saul was king, you led our nation in battle. And the LORD promised that someday you would rule Israel and take care of us like a shepherd."
5.3: During the meeting, David made an agreement with the leaders and asked the LORD to be their witness. Then the leaders poured olive oil on David's head to show that he was now the king of Israel.
5.4: David was 30 years old when he became king, and he ruled for 40 years.
5.5: He lived in Hebron for the first seven and a half years and ruled only Judah. Then he moved to Jerusalem, where he ruled both Israel and Judah for 33 years.
5.6: The Jebusites lived in Jerusalem, and David led his army there to attack them. The Jebusites did not think he could get in, so they told him, "You can't get in here! We could keep you out, even if we couldn't see or walk!"
5.10: David became a great and strong ruler, because the LORD All-Powerful was on his side.
5.11: King Hiram of Tyre sent some officials to David. Carpenters and stone workers came with them, and they brought cedar logs so they could build David a palace.
5.12: David knew that the LORD had made him king of Israel and that he had made him a powerful ruler for the good of his people.
5.13: After David left Hebron and moved to Jerusalem, he married many women from Jerusalem, and he had a lot of children.
5.14: His sons who were born there were Shammua, Shobab, Nathan, Solomon,
5.17: The Philistines heard that David was now king of Israel, and they came into the hill country to try and capture him. But David found out and went into his fortress.
5.18: So the Philistines camped in Rephaim Valley.
5.19: David asked the LORD, "Should I attack the Philistines? Will you let me win?" The LORD told David, "Attack! I will let you win."
5.20: David attacked the Philistines and defeated them. Then he said, "I watched the LORD break through my enemies like a mighty flood." So he named the place "The Lord Broke Through."
5.21: David and his troops also carried away the idols that the Philistines had left behind.
5.22: Some time later, the Philistines came back into the hill country and camped in Rephaim Valley.
5.23: David asked the LORD what he should do, and the LORD answered: Don't attack them from the front. Circle around behind and attack from among the balsam trees.
5.24: Wait until you hear a sound in the treetops like marching troops. Then attack quickly! That sound will mean I have marched out ahead of you to fight the Philistine army.
5.25: David obeyed the LORD and defeated the Philistines. He even chased them all the way from Geba to the entrance to Gezer.

6.1: David brought together 30,000 of Israel's best soldiers and
6.2: led them to Baalah in Judah, which was also called Kiriath-Jearim. They were going there to get the sacred chest and bring it back to Jerusalem. The throne of the LORD All-Powerful is above the winged creatures on top of this chest, and he is worshiped there.
6.3: They put the sacred chest on a new ox cart and started bringing it down the hill from Abinadab's house. Abinadab's sons Uzzah and Ahio were guiding the ox cart,
6.4: with Ahio walking in front of it.
6.5: Some of the people of Israel were playing music on small harps and other stringed instruments, and on tambourines, castanets, and cymbals. David and the others were happy, and they danced for the LORD with all their might.
6.6: But when they came to Nacon's threshing-floor, the oxen stumbled, so Uzzah reached out and took hold of the sacred chest.
6.7: The LORD God was very angry with Uzzah for doing this, and he killed Uzzah right there beside the chest.
6.8: David got angry with God for killing Uzzah. He named that place "Bursting Out Against Uzzah," and that's what it's still called.
6.9: David was afraid of the LORD and thought, "Should I really take the sacred chest to my city?"
6.10: He decided not to take it there. Instead, he turned off the road and took it to the home of Obed Edom, who was from Gath.
6.13: The people carrying the chest walked six steps, then David sacrificed an ox and a choice cow.
6.14: He was dancing for the LORD with all his might, but he wore only a linen cloth.
6.15: He and everyone else were celebrating by shouting and blowing horns while the chest was being carried along.
6.16: Saul's daughter Michal looked out her window and watched the chest being brought into David's City. But when she saw David jumping and dancing for the LORD, she was disgusted.
6.17: They put the chest inside a tent that David had set up for it. David worshiped the LORD by sacrificing animals and burning them on an altar,
6.18: then he blessed the people in the name of the LORD All-Powerful.

7.1: King David moved into his new palace, and the LORD let his kingdom be at peace.

7.5: to go to David and give him this message: David, you are my servant, so listen to what I say. Why should you build a temple for me?
7.6: I didn't live in a temple when I brought my people out of Egypt, and I don't live in one now. A tent has always been my home wherever I have gone with them.
7.7: I chose leaders and told them to be like shepherds for my people Israel. But did I ever say anything to even one of them about building a cedar temple for me?
7.8: David, this is what I, the LORD All-Powerful, say to you. I brought you in from the fields where you took care of sheep, and I made you the leader of my people.
7.9: Wherever you went, I helped you and destroyed your enemies right in front of your eyes. I have made you one of the most famous people in the world.
7.10: I have given my people Israel a land of their own where they can live in peace, and they won't have to tremble with fear any more. Evil nations won't bother them, as they did
7.11: when I let judges rule my people. And I have kept your enemies from attacking you. Now I promise that you and your descendants will be kings.

7.13: and no one will be able to take his kingdom away from him. He will be the one to build a temple for me.
7.14: I will be his father, and he will be my son. When he does wrong, I'll see that he is corrected, just as children are corrected by their parents.

7.16: I will make sure that one of your descendants will always be king.
7.17: Nathan told David exactly what he had heard in the vision.
7.18: David went into the tent he had set up for the sacred chest. Then he sat there and prayed: LORD All-Powerful, my family and I don't deserve what you have already done for us,
7.19: and yet you have promised to do even more. Is this the way you usually treat people?
7.20: I am your servant, and you know my thoughts, so there is nothing more that I need to say.
7.21: You have done this wonderful thing, and you have let me know about it, because you wanted to keep your promise.
7.22: LORD All-Powerful, you are greater than all others. No one is like you, and you alone are God. Everything we have heard about you is true.
7.23: And there is no other nation on earth like Israel, the nation you rescued from slavery in Egypt to be your own. You became famous by using great and wonderful miracles to force other nations and their gods out of your land, so your people could live here.
7.24: You have chosen Israel to be your people forever, and you have become their God.
7.25: And now, LORD God, please do what you have promised me and my descendants.
7.26: Then you will be famous forever, and everyone will say, "The LORD God All-Powerful rules Israel, and David's descendants are his chosen kings."
7.27: After all, you really are Israel's God, the LORD All-Powerful. You've told me that you will let my descendants be kings. That's why I have the courage to pray to you like this, even though I am only your servant.
7.28: LORD All-Powerful, you are God. You have promised me some very good things, and you can be trusted to do what you promise.
7.29: Please bless my descendants and let them always be your chosen kings. You have already promised, and I'm sure that you will bless my family forever.

9.1: One day, David thought, "I wonder if any of Saul's family are still alive. If they are, I will be kind to them, because I made a promise to Jonathan."

9.3: David asked, "Are any of Saul's family still alive? If there are, I want to be kind to them." Ziba answered, "One of Jonathan's sons is still alive, but he can't walk."
9.4: "Where is he?" David asked. Ziba replied, "He lives in Lo-Debar with Machir the son of Ammiel."
9.7: David said, "Don't be afraid. I'll be kind to you because Jonathan was your father. I'm going to give you back the land that belonged to your grandfather Saul. Besides that, you will always eat with me at my table."

10.7: David heard what they had done, and he sent out Joab with all of his well-trained soldiers.

10.13: Joab and his soldiers attacked the Arameans, and the Arameans ran from them.

10.19: When the kings who had been under Hadadezer's rule saw that Israel had beaten them, they made peace with Israel and accepted David as their ruler. The Arameans were afraid to help Ammon any more.

12.15: Then Nathan went back home. The LORD made David's young son very sick.

12.23: But now that he's dead, why should I go without eating? I can't bring him back! Someday I will join him in death, but he can't return to me.

13.1: David had a beautiful daughter named Tamar, who was the sister of Absalom. She was also the half sister of Amnon, who fell in love with her.
13.2: But Tamar was a virgin, and Amnon could not think of a way to be alone with her. He was so upset about it that he made himself sick.
13.3: Amnon had a friend named Jonadab, who was the son of David's brother Shimeah. Jonadab always knew how to get what he wanted,
13.4: and he said to Amnon, "What's the matter? You're the king's son! You shouldn't have to go around feeling sorry for yourself every morning." Amnon said, "I'm in love with Tamar, my brother Absalom's sister."
13.5: Jonadab told him, "Lie down on your bed and pretend to be sick. When your father comes to see you, ask him to send Tamar, so you can watch her cook something for you. Then she can serve you the food."
13.6: So Amnon went to bed and pretended to be sick. When the king came to see him, Amnon said, "Please, ask Tamar to come over. She can make some special bread while I watch, and then she can serve it to me."
13.7: David told Tamar, "Go over to Amnon's house and fix him some food."
13.8: When she got there, he was lying in bed. She mixed the dough, made the loaves, and baked them while he watched.
13.9: Then she took the bread out of the pan and put it on his plate, but he refused to eat it. Amnon said, "Send the servants out of the house." After they had gone,
13.10: he said to Tamar, "Serve the food in my bedroom." Tamar picked up the bread that she had made and brought it into Amnon's bedroom.
13.11: But as she was taking it over to him, he grabbed her and said, "Come to bed with me!"
13.12: She answered, "No! Please don't force me! This sort of thing isn't done in Israel. It's disgusting!
13.13: Think of me. I'll be disgraced forever! And think of yourself. Everyone in Israel will say you're nothing but trash! Just ask the king, and he will let you marry me."
13.14: But Amnon would not listen to what she said. He was stronger than she was, so he overpowered her and raped her.
13.15: Then Amnon hated her even more than he had loved her before. So he told her, "Get up and get out!"
13.16: She said, "Don't send me away! That would be worse than what you have already done." But Amnon would not listen.
13.17: He called in his servant and said, "Throw this woman out and lock the door!"
13.18: The servant made her leave, and he locked the door behind her. The king's unmarried daughters used to wear long robes with sleeves.
13.19: Tamar tore the robe she was wearing and put ashes on her head. Then she covered her face with her hands and cried loudly as she walked away.
13.20: Tamar's brother Absalom said to her, "How could Amnon have done such a terrible thing to you! But since he's your brother, don't tell anyone what happened. Just try not to think about it." Tamar soon moved into Absalom's house, but she was always sad and lonely.
13.21: When David heard what had happened to Tamar, he was very angry. But Amnon was his oldest son and also his favorite, and David would not do anything to make Amnon unhappy.
13.22: Absalom treated Amnon as though nothing had happened, but he hated Amnon for what he had done to his sister Tamar.
13.23: Two years later, Absalom's servants were cutting wool from his sheep in Baal-Hazor near the town of Ephraim, and Absalom invited all of the king's sons to be there.
13.24: Then he went to David and said, "My servants are cutting the wool from my sheep. Please come and join us!"
13.25: David answered, "No, my son, we won't go. It would be too expensive for you." Absalom tried to get him to change his mind, but David did not want to go. He only said that he hoped they would have a good time.
13.26: Absalom said, "If you won't go, at least let my brother Amnon come with us." David asked, "Why should he go with you?"
13.27: But Absalom kept on insisting, and finally David let Amnon and all his other sons go with Absalom. Absalom prepared a banquet fit for a king.
13.28: But he told his servants, "Keep an eye on Amnon. When he gets a little drunk from the wine and is feeling relaxed, I'll give the signal. Then kill him! I've commanded you to do it, so don't be afraid. Be strong and brave."
13.29: Absalom's servants killed Amnon, just as Absalom had told them. The rest of the king's sons quickly rode away on their mules to escape from Absalom.
13.30: While they were on their way to Jerusalem, someone told David, "Absalom has killed all of your sons! Not even one is left."
13.31: David got up, and in his sorrow he tore his clothes and lay down on the ground. His servants remained standing, but they tore their clothes too.
13.32: Then David's nephew Jonadab said, "Your Majesty, not all of your sons were killed! Only Amnon is dead. On the day that Amnon raped Tamar, Absalom decided to kill him.
13.33: Don't worry about the report that all your sons were killed. Only Amnon is dead,
13.34: and Absalom has run away." One of the guards noticed a lot of people coming along the hillside on the road to Horonaim. He went and told the king, "I saw some men coming along Horonaim Road."
13.35: Jonadab said, "Your Majesty, look! Here come your sons now, just as I told you."
13.36: No sooner had he said it, than David's sons came in. They were weeping out loud, and David and all his officials cried just as loudly.
